newsitem.title: UK: Scotland could be "tiger" of Europe - nationalists.
newsitem.headline: Scotland could be "tiger" of Europe - nationalists.

text.p: The leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) said on Friday that an independent Scotland could become the economic "tiger" of Europe and cited the growth rates now seen in Ireland.

SNP chief Alex Salmond, who was delivering a keynote speech to the party's annual conference in Inverness later on Friday, said Ireland would in three years' time be more prosperous per head of population than England.
"On current growth levels, Ireland will become more prosperous than the UK and Scotland by the year 2000. They have already overtaken the Welsh," Salmond said in a statement.
"But compared to Scotland, Ireland has next to no resources. They have used their imagination and human resources in order to drive their economy forward.
"With the freedom of independence, Scotland could combine our own talents with the nation's abundant resources, and make Scotland the 'tiger economy' of Europe," Salmond said.
Salmond based his forecast on research carried out for the party by the House of Commons library in London.

This concluded that Irish gross domestic product per head was projected "to have exceeded that of Wales in 1995 and will exceed that of Scotland, and the UK as a whole, by the year 2000", provided Ireland maintained its recent high growth rates.
The SNP maintains that an independent Scotland would be the 21st richest country in the world. Some economists think Salmond's forecasts for the Irish economy are several years too optimistic.

The SNP, holding its last annual conference before a general election that must be held by next May, are enjoying strong support of 29 percent at the polls, largely due to a series of Scottish policy gaffes by Labour, their main rivals.

But the party was still struggling to contain the crisis that erupted after a senior party figure compared the opposition Labour party's Scottish affairs spokesman to a World War Two Nazi collaborator.
SNP deputy policy chief Alex Neil used a podium speech to liken Labour's Scottish spokesman George Robertson to Lord Haw Haw, the Nazi broadcaster who was hanged for treason in 1946.
Labour called for Neil to resign, and under pressure from the SNP leadership he apologised for any personal slight to Robertson.

Margaret Ewing, an SNP member of the British parliament, sought to play down the gaffe, accusing the media of looking for splits in party ranks. She described Neil's remarks as "a joke that maybe misfired".
